Identifying Characteristics: Irregularly shaped dark spots that adorn their backs and legs
Each spot is normally bordered by a lighter ring
Greenish-brown in color with a pearly white underside and light-colored ridges on either side of their backs
Pale stripe running from the nostril, under the eye and tympanum and terminating at the shoulder
Ventral surface is white or pale green
Tadpoles are dark brown or grey, with light blotches on the underside
Size: adults can be 3-5 inches long
Biology: Males make a short snore-like call from water during spring and summer
The northern leopard frog breeds in the spring (March–June)
Up to 6500 eggs are laid in water and tadpoles complete development within the breeding pond
Tadpoles are light brown with black spots and development takes 70–110 days (depending on conditions)
Metamorph frogs are 2–3 cm long and resemble the adult
Females are slightly larger than males
Habitat: Normally inhabit water bodies with abundant aquatic vegetation
Sometimes venture into well-covered grasslands as well (also called the meadow frog)
Can be found in permanent ponds, swamps, marshes, and slow-moving streams throughout forest, open, and urban areas In summer they often abandon ponds and move to grassy areas and lawns
Diet: Eat just about anything they can fit in their mouths (beetles, ants, flies, worms, smaller frogs, including their own species, and even birds, and garter snakes)
Range: Western Canada and the United States
